Title: Alistair Logan's Lockdown Haircut

Description:
Last year I was unfortunately diagnosed with cancer. Whilst receiving Chemotherapy, I was feeling sorry for myself and was bored with feeling tired and yukky all the time. It was then I came up with an idea.

I decided to have a get better list. NOT a bucket list because a bucket list is things to do before you die, but I am planning to be around for a long time yet. Anyway, for every chemo treatment I have added an activity. They are all quite crazy things such as indoor sky diving; trampoline Parks; Go Ape etc. You get the sort of idea

The next event is taking place on Saturday the 9th June. My daughter has bought the family and I a very strange experience. We are going to be flung off the Killiecrankie bridge on a Bungee Swing. I told her that I was no longer scared of anything but really?!?

Well here is where you come in. I thought while doing this it may be a good idea to raise money for a good cause. I am hoping to raise money for The Storehouse Foodbank, which is run by the Falkirk VIneyard Church. This is a very important charity and very close to my heart. It seeks to help disadvantaged families in our local areas by providing them with food and other essentials in a time of crisis. If you feel you could contribute anything then I wold be really grateful and it may give the extra incentive to fly off the bridge.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and thank you for your generosity.

With lots of love

Michelle

Description:
As we all prepare to celebrate the festive season as best we can during the coronavirus pandemic, it's more important than ever to remember those who have been affected by job loss, illness, bereavement and the many other issues facing people during this difficult year. The Trussell Trust aims to end the need for food banks and at this time needs all the help it can get. 100,000 people needed foodbanks for the first time at the start of the pandemic and this Christmas, 670,000 more people will fall into destitution and become unable to afford the essentials of life, let alone the luxuries we all enjoy at Christmas.

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. Itâ€™s not right that people canâ€™t afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks.As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Walking in the beautiful Hampshire countryside is something I enjoy doing most days, so I wanted to set myself the goal of walking a total of 100 miles between the start of the second lockdown (November 5th) and December 31st with the aim of raising Â£1, 000 for the Trussell Trust. I would be enormously grateful for any donation you are able to make. Thank you so much!

Thank you for supporting S6 Foodbank. Every donation made goes directly to support their work.

Without the assistance of people and businesses in Sheffield, S6 Foodbank wouldnt be able to continue to support their guests, launch new sites and tackle the ongoing food crisis in Sheffield which is being exacerbated by coronavirus.

S6 Foodbank are expecting the increased need to continue for the foreseeable future, as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. 

A donation of Â£27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three for three days. I am aiming to raise at least Â£40 to help S6 Foodbank reach their Â£40,000 target. Whatever I raise (up to that target) will be match-funded by the Government via the Love Your Neighbour partnership, meaning S6 Foodbank receives double the amount.

Description:
Miranda's Big Stitch

Between 1 June and 31 August 2021, I will be cross-stitching a version of Van Gogh's The Starry Night to raise money for Hull Foodbank.

Having previously completed a 24-hour stitchathon and a year-long stitching challenge where I produced numerous smaller pieces, I thought I'd try my hand at one bigger piece this time. And big it is: at nearly 50,000 stitches, it should take me around 250 hours to complete. In other words, I'll have to do over 2.5 hours of stitching a day to get it ready by the deadline - well, it is meant to be a challenge!

I have chosen to fundraise for Hull Foodbank because, although I really wish foodbanks weren't needed, I fear they're unlikely to become surplus to requirements any time soon.

You can follow my progress on my FB page - just search for 'Miranda's Big Stitch'..

Thank you for reading.

It also saves time running away from people shaking a bucket at you. You can do so anonymously or with your name and a good luck message.

My aim for the BIG DAY is to identify 100 different species of birds on my patch - that is, on foot from my home in Wivenhoe, on 27th April.

I'll follow up this event with a bird finding series. You pay me an amount to find you a bird you've always wanted to see and enjoy. Really elusive or exotic birds will require a premium!

I'll reserve the 28th as a back-up day in case the weather is foul on 27th.

Thanks for reading this far and for considering helping Colchester Food Bank. If you want the money to be specifically reserved for Wivenhoe, say so on your message, but Colchester supports us with its warehousing and management, so it all helps!

Glynâ€™s Wivenhoe Bird Race
At precisely 4.30am I was aware of light filtering through the bedroom curtains...
Aaaagh â€“ Iâ€™d missed my alarm! Fortunately, my accomplice for the day, Nick Green, had not and was making tea for a quick vigil on the back patio before we set out on the long tramp around Wivenhoe.
Although I had done some scouting for key breeding birds on territory, the cold, windy conditions would make it something of a lottery on the day â€“ especially at dawn â€“ as to whether the birds would betray their presence with any song.
The Tawny Owls we might have hoped to hear from the back patio drew a blank. The wind was such that we could not hear anything from the estuary as we sometimes can, so we set off at 04.55 for Ferry Marsh. High tide, for what it was worth (it wasnâ€™t going to be e big one) was at around 07.30, so we simply walked around ferry marsh on the sea wall (it is still impassable due to flooding) without lingering. We picked up Sedge, Reed and Cettis warbler without any effort, plus Common & Lesser Whitethroat in the dawn chorus. No Chiffchaffs were heard until we walked back through the woods after looping through them from Lower Lodge after the return journey from opposite the Hythe on the trail. Along the river, we predictably scored Greenshank, Nightingale (2 territorial males either side of the river at Hythe), Common Tern and the more common waders, but no Spotted Redshank or Ruff as we might have hoped. A male Sparrowhawk swooped past us near the Uni and Bullfinches were barely audible above the breeze at the level crossing. The otherwise time-saving scope from Lower Lodge to the lagoons was passed up, but at great distance it would have been nigh impossible to see the Green Sandpipers and other smaller waders from that distance. We had seen 3 Avocets on the estuary the previous day, so felt confident that we would connect more easily than a long-range scan. With just over 2 hours to walk to the Hythe and then Wivenhoe Woods en route to Alresford Creek for high tide, we moved quite quickly. No Nightingales were in song in Wivenhoe wood. In fact, very few birds were evident. There were a couple of Jays to keep the total ticking over but by now, the lack of bird song was slightly concerning. A Cuckoo did at least make itself heard from across the river.
Back on the trail after Wivenhoe Woods, we connected with House Martins around West Quay. The walk to the creek yielded only Whimbrel and Bar-tailed Godwit, so we arrived at the metal bench with 40 minutes to scan across to Geedon Marsh before our breakfast rendezvous with Mark Norrington. A brief stop at the barrier did not yield Grey Wagtail, as hoped.
The vigil and the walk along to the bottom of Ford Lane for bacon rolls and coffee, courtesy of Mark, moved the species total from 62 to 71. We darted back to the creek mouth watch point as the wader and wildfowl count to that point was paltry... It seemed evident that most, if not all the usual wintering wildfowl and waders had cleared out, such that, other than the plentiful Whimbrels, we did not add anywhere near the numbers at Alresford that we had hoped, with Golden, Grey and Ringed Plover, Knot, Avocet, Spotted Redshank and Common Sandpiper all absent, as well as Wigeon, Teal and Brent Goose â€“ all of which we would have expected.
We felt that we were 15 species short of where we needed to be when we dragged ourselves away from the creek with 79 species to our name, with one Mediterranean Gull making itself heard above the breeze. At least Little Owl provided an easy hit at Plumptons farm; Buzzards and Marsh Harriers were showing regularly without any thermals to speak of, but there were no more exotic raptors or larger migrants to add. We would have another chance with a later (not very) high tide late in the day, but at this stage, a total of 100 looked very distant, if not impossible without a significant fall of passage migrants. The walk along Cutthroat Lane to Sunnymead & Cockaynes was very quiet. Our remaining hopes of Treecreeper and Coal Tit would be at Cockaynes or Villa wood.
To our abject dismay, there was no Willow Warbler or Garden Warbler in song at Cockaynes. As the clock neared 1pm, I called Debbie to suggest she stays at home rather than deliver our lunch. Discretion became the better part and we managed to trek across Ballast Quay track to aarive back at home for an extended lunch break and a discussion on how we were even going to get over 90, let alone 100.
The biggest gaps in the list of hopefuls (if no longer probables) were of estuarine species, notable by their absence in the first tidal phase. Other incidental passerine species and their likely sites were well spread across the area. The other issue was that Nick had only just recovered from illness and we had already walked 12 miles on just a few hours sleep...
By the time we had eaten as many turkey sandwiches as we could, Nick had retired for a â€œlie downâ€. I thought that this would be effectively the end of his participation so togged up again and decided to head out to the creek, via the trail, to see if I could mop up some migrants and to get much luckier with estuarine species. Realistically, this was highly unlikely, but in the context of achieving the highest possible total, this was the obvious option.
To my amazement, as I neared the jetty, Nick called to say that he had woken after barely 30 minutes! We agreed to meet at the creek. By then, I had caught up with the pair of Grey Wagtails on the barrier having heard the male gently singing there from the jetty. The two birds showed briefly before I marched determinedly toward Nick.
Whilst there was nothing new on Barrier Marsh, I was tempted to stop briefly for a Nightingale that was very close to the path in an elevated position. I managed to zoom through a small opening to pick out the bird with the camera and stole quite a pleasing shot.
By the time I reached Nick at the bench, all threats of rain had gone and we enjoyed the next 90 minutes in mostly bright sunshine, doing our best to identify silhouetted images between us and Geedon saltings.
In this time, Nick did brilliantly to pick out a lone Brent Goose and I was able to lock on to a Great White Egret over the saltings. This put us on 82 for the day, but it was now obvious that the estuarine species had all but moved on. A flock of Dunlins were still in the creek, some of which were in almost full summer plumage, as were the Turnstones and 2 of the half dozen or so Bar-tailed Godwits to raise the spirits a little.
Had we stayed out for the rest of the day until dark, we might have added 2 or 3 more species, but there was no way we were going to get near 100, so we called it a day and declared our innings total at 82 species with 17 miles walked.
At the time of writing, we have raised Â£320 plus GiftAid. I will be doing other activities in a bid to raise this, including a bird finding schedule and making greeting cards with wildlife photos to benefit the Food Bank.

Every year, Transmit organises a donation to Gateshead Foodbank to help put together their Christmas Hampers, and make a real difference to someone's Christmas. We have distributed donation boxes across the business centres in Gateshead Baltic Quarter and asked residents to donate a few items requested by the foodbanks. We understand not everyone can get to the business centres, but would still like to donate. 

Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, the Trussell Trustâ€™s food bank network distributed 1,600,000 three-day emergency food supplies to those in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children.  
88,708 of these emergency food parcels were supplied in the North East of England. 

As Christmas draws close, it is important we help those who need it and spread a little joy. All donations are really appreciated and gratefully received.

Title: Kai and Oliver Rochford's Charity Drive

Description:
We are passionate St.Mirren supporters who run the Black & White Army supporters website and twitter page (@bawarmy).

On Dec 2nd we launched what we thought would be a bit of community minded festive fun ahead of a huge run of pre-Christmas fixtures for our team.

With Christmas on the way we are even more mindful of those in our local community who are struggling and following up on the amazingly successful Foodbank collections we've seen at the stadium in recent times we thought we'd join in and try and raise some funds for the Renfrewshire Foodbank.

Our challenge to the team was simple. For every point gained in the four fixtures leading up to Christmas the B&W Army site would donate Â£25 to the foodbank.That meant a glorious 12 point haul against Motherwell, Hamilton, Livingston and St.Johnstone would lead to a whopping Â£300 donation.

So then we started getting messages from other fans who wanted to join in, and it started to grow and grow and grow and we had pledges coming in from all over the place. That list of heroes who pledged is shown on our own site here at this link;

https://www.blackandwhitearmy.com/12pointsofchristmas

An incredible Â£2648 per point, pledged by almost 500 supporters!!!

The plan was, and still is, to tally up our points haul after the four matches and to contact all our pledgers on 22nd December to ask for their final donation.

We have however decided to open up the page now for a number of reasons;

1) Some supporters just want to make a one-off contribution
2) Plenty fans want to donate regardless of the results.We can't lie. There is always a risk that we lose all the games :-(
3) Fans can donate as they go, rather than all in one lump at the end
4) We appreciate the Foodbank may be especially stretched at this time of year.
5) We completely appreciate that everyones finances get hammered at this time of year!

So here we are, the page is open. We obviously don't know what our target is going to be as it will be dependent on the points we gain, but we're starting off with a 1 point target of Â£2648.

We will adjust and update the page as the matches are played.

Thanks to each and every person who has pledged and who has supported and shared this. Other football fans have also joined in which has been massively appreciated, and some of them aren't even from Renfrewshire which is even more amazing!

Title: T's Christmas Appeal

Description:
Hi everyone,

2020 has been a difficult year for everyone but clearly some are affected more than others. Having had a lot of support from the Weymouth community after starting my new business venture, I wanted to look at ways to give something back in return. 

I have never been a runner and at 56 years of age could not see me starting to put the lycra on so I have looked at something that most of us could do and that is walk. My day usually consists of working up to 12 hours, so I will be walking every day come rain, shine or even snow but will have to fit in around my work by doing this very early in the morning or later in the evening. However, I planned to do a fixed walk a week when anybody could come and join me for support or to just get a bit of extra exercise. LOCKDOWN HAS CHANGED THIS UNFORTUNATELY but I can still walk with one person so if you would like to join me then please contact me prior so that we do not have more than one at a time. This will be on every Sunday at 9.30am  starting at the Oasis Cafe at Overcombe and walking to Weymouth Pavilion and back. This is 4.51 miles (7.25 km) and with a brisk pace takes an hour and 10/15 minutes. Please feel free to join me and get a shout out on one of the regular video updates. The 500 km walk will finish when it finishes but could take 2 months which will help to extend the fund raising period.

As a local Estate Agent, I pledge Â£50 for everyone of my personal completed sales throughout 2021. This is in addition to the Â£1500 target I have given and would like to smash

Having researched and spoken to the brilliant people that run the Weymouth Foodbank, I was staggered to learn that 15% of the Weymouth population live with food insecurity. Since lockdown the foodbank has gone from supporting up to 40 local families to up to 90 families and supply food that gives three balanced meals a day for a three day period. Support from the local community when doing their regular weekly shopping, by placing extra items into foodbank trolley's are extremely valuable. So much more is required to put these supplies together from the three outlets in Weymouth such as tinned meats, tinned vegetables, tinned fruit along with fresh ingredients such as milk, cheese, bread etc which have a short shelf life. In addition to this there is a warehouse on the Granby Industrial Estate that also requires funds for insurance, and general running costs.

Thank you in advance for your support

Jon Williams

Title: Donation Match

Description:
Since our launch in October 2012 Angus foodbank has received donations of 178 tons of food and fed 19,000 people 4,700 being children.  We work with over 100 organisations who refer people to our foodbank, who through various circumstances are unable to afford to buy enough food to keep body and soul together.

Many of the people who come to the foodbank are very embarrassed and and down trodden but it is amazing how often they will return up to a year  later and remind us that they received a food parcel but that having found a new job or help with their situation they now want to make a donation back to the foodbank.

However we still need money to run the foodbank, to pay utility bills, purchase and running costs for our delivery van and other expenses.  We have 1 paid member of staff, our Manager, and 80 volunteers who do a power of work collecting and sorting the donated food and dealing with the people who are in need in a caring and compassionate way.

YOUR HELP IS APPRECIATED

Title: Janet's plant sale

Description:
63 Air Assault Support Squadron RLC will be commemorating the 75th anniversary of VE Day by collectively completing a 75-hour triathlon.

75 soldiers and officers from the squadron will volunteer for one-hour slots to have all three disciplines in motion over 75 hours. There are 225 slots in total! The challenge will begin at 08:00hrs on Tuesday 5th May and conclude at 11:00hrs on Friday 8th May - just in time for the two-minute silence that the Nation will be observing to commemorate VE Day 75.

Why are we doing this? Due to the current pandemic, the nation has had very little cause for celebration recently. We want to do our upmost to commemorate this momentous day in history which saw WW2 come to an end in Europe.

In true British spirit we will also be rallying together to support two great charities: Colchester Foodbank and the Airborne Museum at Hartenstein.   

Colchester Foodbank supports people in poverty and in crisis. They provide nutritionally balanced emergency food and welfare support to local people who are referred to them. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. The foodbank is run by local people for local people, and they rely on the communityâ€™s support to provide much-needed help to people in crisis.  Our contributions will help them maintain essential stocks of key products, as well as running sustainable local projects.

The Airborne Museum at Hartenstein in Oosterbeek, Netherlands, commemorates the most famous parachute operation in the history of Airborne Forces â€“ the Battle of Arnhem. The museum not only tells the story of the battle, but it is also a centre for international remembrance. They have come into financial difficulty after their grand-reopening was cancelled by the COVID-19 lockdown. The museum is dependent on funding from visitors and their continued operation has been jeopardised by the global pandemic. 

Any sharing, support, or donations, however small, will be hugely appreciated by all of us at 63 Squadron and our chosen charities.

No more than 3 people at any one time will be exercising and all will be compliant with the Governmentâ€™s guidance on social distancing. Please stay at home, save lives, and protect the NHS!

Thank you for supporting our challenge!
Title: VE Day 75 Triathlon

Description:
I will be doing PE with Joe every day in May (including weekends by doing past workouts) to raise money for the Kirkcaldy Foodbank Covid-19 Crisis Appeal. You won't be able to see me do it, but you'll know I did when I emerge from lockdown with a replica of Joe Wicks' body.

We are all staying at home due to the Coronavirus pandemic. While we are all in this together, some people are hit harder. Please take the time to help those in food poverty. 

It is the mission of Kirkcaldy Foodbank that nobody in the Kirkcaldy area goes hungry during a time of crisis and that everybody shares what they have. Kirkcaldy Foodbank has always relied upon donations and volunteers from the community. During this current Coronavirus pandemic, the foodbank has recorded a sharp rise in numbers and it is asking for your help to fund the purchase of food that is required to fill this gap. If you are able to work from home at this time, why not donate the cost of your commute - petrol, bus, train to help Kirkcaldy Foodbank. If you would like to donate food, Kirkcaldy Foodbank have a number of donation points which can be found on our website http://www.kirkcaldyfoodbank.org.uk/Index.asp?MainID=21286

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For the last 3 years I have played Father Christmas at Rowans Hospice Christmas Fair which obviously didn't happen this year and I'm aware that there are far fewer opportunities for children to see Father Christmas and visit grottos in 2020 so I have decided to make recorded messages from Santa for anybody who wants one.

If you would like a video, copy and paste the following link into your browser and fill in your details on the page:
https://forms.gle/dnVvvDbV3RFaPK1X8

For each video I am asking for a small donation to Portsmouth Food Bank. No child should go hungry at Christmas or any other time of the year. From February 2019 to February 2020 Portmouth Food Bank fed 8950 people. I really dread to think how much that number has increased over the last year with everything that's been going on. I'm sure they're going to need all the help they can get.

I'm certainly not claiming I'm a brilliant Father Christmas, I have a drama degree (who hasn't??) the outfit isn't the most expensive, the setting will likely be my living room rather than a grotto and I will only have access to a basic (free) video editor so the production won't be outstanding. But it will be Father Christmas giving a personalised message to your kid(s) and will hopefully add a little bit of extra magic to Christmas for the little people.
Title: Daniel's Father Christmas Recorded Messages

Description:
#NoChildHungry

This half term, Transforming Exercise & Nutrition LTD want to do our bit to help ðŸ–¤

There are many local children who will be going hungry this half term, since the Government is no longer providing vouchers for children in poverty for free school meals during school holidays...

So, our TEN coaches and many of our TEN participants will be taking part in a 450 burpee challenge from Monday 26th October - Sunday 1st November! 

Thatâ€™s 1 burpee for every child registered with Colchester Food Bank!

We are doing this with the aim to try and raise Â£450 in total for Colchester FoodBank and to also encourage local people to donate some much needed food to the charity ðŸ’«

Did you know that a third of those in crisis that Colchester FoodBank feeds are children? 2020 has already been their busiest year ever. 

As Colchester's Bishop Roger Morris from the Diocese of Chelmsford says in his keynote speech, child poverty should already be history. No child in our nation should be starving. 

Hereâ€™s the details of Colchester FoodBankâ€™s website, if youâ€™d like to drop off a food parcel in place of a sponsorship:

https://colchester.foodbank.org.uk/

Finally, please do ask your MPs to help and if possible sign the petition asking the Government to support vulnerable children; #endchildfoodpoverty by implementing 3 recommendations from the National Food Strategy to expand access to Free School Meals, provide meals; activities during holidays to stop holiday hunger; increase the value of and expand the Healthy Start scheme.

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554276

Thank you everyone ðŸ–¤ðŸš€

- Amy & The TEN Team

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Everybody is affected by the pandemic in some way or another, some more than others.

We may not be all in the same boat we are all sailing the same storm.

I am Ross Malyon currently part of Warlingham FC and the recent events I felt it was necessary as an individual and as a club to get the local community together to make a difference. 

So I am helping Caterham foodbank who are our local Foodbank and are part of the Trussell Trust network of foodbanks in the UK. www.trusselltrust.org.

In the UK, more than 14 million people are living in poverty â€“ including 4.5 million children. We support more than 1,200 food bank centres in the UK to provide a minimum of three daysâ€™ nutritionally-balanced emergency food to people who have been referred in crisis, as well as support to help people resolve the crises they face. Between April 2019 and March 2020, food banks in our network provided a record 1.9 million food supplies to people in crisis, an 18% increase on the previous year.

We know it takes more than food to end hunger. Thatâ€™s why we bring together the experiences of food banks in our network to challenge the structural economic issues that lock people in poverty, and campaign to end the need for food banks in the UK.

If you would like to help us make a difference all donations will be greatly received ðŸ™ðŸ»

Description:
On the night of 25th January members of 40th Greenwich Scout Troop will be sleeping outside overnight in cardboard boxes to raise money for the Greenwich Foodbank.  The Met Office is forecasting temperatures to reach -1 C and last year the Scouts woke up to find their cardboard boxes covered in snow. 

We are packing our thermals, wooly hats and gloves. Hopefully we will get some sleep...

The Greenwich Foodbank provide nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to them in crisis. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. G40 are proud to support this local charity.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

This term all the children in year 5 took part in the Newcastle Building Society Boardroom Challenge which required us to come up with an idea for an event in support of a local charity. As a team we all decided we'd love to break a world record to support our school charity, The Gateshead Foodbank. We looked through the World Records database and found that the record for the World's Longest Food Passing Relay was yet to be broken. We thought that attempting this record would be a great way to raise awareness of and funding for the Foodbank.

To break the world record for the Worldâ€™s Longest Food Passing
Relay we will need a minimum of 1000 people and 10 items of food. To achieve the record everyone must stand in a long line (like a very long snake!) and the first person in the line must pass each food item to the next person in line, and so on until all 1000 people have held each item of food. If we can achieve this we will have broken a world record!

Anyone is welcome to take part in our record attempt. However, even if you don't wish to take part you can still donate money to our cause. Wish us luck!

Description:
In the last few years a December donation for our local food bank has became an office tradition. Last year each team across the office donated a (very generous) box of goods and the total amount of food took hours and numerous car trips to transport to the food bank warehouse!

This year is more challenging due to working from home and the restrictions we are all having to live with. Sadly also, the pandemic has seen a vastly increased number of people needing to use the food banks services due to COVID and the subsequent effect on jobs and the economy, with the North East continuing to be hit hard with no end yet in sight. Therefore it is really important we find a way to support them, and an online cash donation is the easiest way to do this, meaning the food bank can use this money to buy goods to give directly to their clients.

We would love to hit the Â£1000 mark, which works out under Â£5 per person across the office, so we are asking everyone to contribute Â£5 or whatever you can afford. Remember to add Gift aid too!

Description:
It is the time of year when the Church gives thanks for the harvest and here at Caldicott we normally take in food for the Slough Foodbank who then distribute it amongst those in need in the area.

Now more than ever, there is need in the community. The pandemic has resulted in an exceptional increase in the number of people finding themselves in a position whereby they are needing help.

However, our local foodbank has asked us if we could take a monetary collection this year instead as they are struggling to keep up with storage and the necessary 'quarantining' of donations. I have fully agreed with this and therefore most humbly ask that rather than sending in small hampers you instead consider making a donation which the good people at the foodbank will use to ensure they have the right things in stock.

Yours ever

James Paget 
Chapel Master

Description:
Hi everyone! I'm Steve, and I have a lovely head full of hair, of which I am very proud.

But not for long.

On Saturday 25th April I'm going to be using my daily exercise to run 10 kilometers around Bridgend (ensuring of course to keep appropriate distance from others.) And since everyone is shaving their heads these days, I'm going to do it totally bald. Not "short and stubbly." I'm giving the razor to my wife, and she takes no prisoners.

This current crisis, like all crises, is hitting the poorest of our borough the hardest. People have lost jobs and income and are struggling now more than ever to make ends meet. Bridgend Foodbank is an essential lifeline to those going through times of real need in our society, so let's help them in every possible way we can to keep providing help through this time.

Thank you for your donations - every little helps, no matter what the amount.

Description:
Bridgend Coronavirus Support Groupâ€™s Â£2 Challenge! 

We've been thinking of a way for our Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group to help people at this difficult time, without asking too much when most of us are anxious about money and the future.

Having kept in touch with the Bridgend Foodbank Charity, we think it will be really helpful to raise money for their volunteer-run base here. They make sure people across Bridgend have emergency food and basics, and rely heavily on donations which are more difficult to safely collect and accept at the moment. 

Our wonderful, supportive and positive group now has 8,000 members from across Bridgend including people who live here, work here and have loved ones here. And we thought, what if each of us donated just Â£2 to Bridgend Foodbank? Collectively we could raise a lot of money for them and make a huge difference to people in our community. 

Please get involved if you can :)

The Just Giving page is linked to the Bridgend Foodbank Donation page and all funds will go directly to them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. You may remember a few years ago, when I got involved in a mad plan to walk 12 walks of 12 miles to mark the 12 men who take their own lives every day!  As a team, we managed to raised something like Â£4,000 for two mental health charities: Movember and CALM. We called it "Walk This Way" - inspired by the classic collaboration between Aerosmith and Run DMC. Collaboration was at the heart of the project, and I remain fiercely proud of what we achieved together.

This time, it is a solo challenge! I've taken my inspiration from "500 Miles (I'm Gonna Be)" by The Proclaimers. Just like the song, I'm going to walk 500 miles.  All walks will be done to be COVID secure and in accordance with the latest guidance from government whether we are in lockdown or out of lockdown. The focus of my challenge this time is to raise money for the amazing Newquay Foodbank who do so much to support the most vulnerable families in this incredible community. It is especially important that these families are supported now, especially as more families have found themselves in unexpected financial hardship as a result of COVID restrictions and two national Lockdowns. 

From a personal perspective, I know what it is like to grow up in a family that was subject to financial hardship and the shadow of poverty when my dad was unemployed back in the 1980s. I remember the humiliation heaped upon me from others as I had to wear second hand clothes (not vintage or pre-loved as they are often referred to now). The memory of that was one of the defining factors that resulted in me becoming a secondary school teacher.  It makes me beyond sad to consider that there will be children in Newquay today who will experience the same or similar things to those that I experienced back when I was young.

So please support me in this challenge. Please spread the news of what I'm trying to do on social media. Please spread the stories of how Newquay Foodbank (and other equally wonderful charities and organisations) are helping those people who are most in need of our help.

And finally... will you be one of my 500 smiles?  I'm looking for at least 500 wonderful people who are willing to donate to this Just Giving page a minimum of Â£5.00 to support the work of Newquay Foodbank throughout this Lockdown and whatever comes after it. That would raise a lot of money to help a lot of people right here in Newquay.

Here's one final music reference for you - anybody and everybody who contributes money to this fundraiser for Newquay Foodbank would undoubtedly become one of my "Heroes"... but for more than one day.

Thank you.

Title: Seb Sando's 8 Marathon Adventure

Description:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We should probably start at the beginningâ€¦
Back in 2000, when I was just 17, I was attacked by a group of four men. I was pretty badly beaten and woke the following day in a hospital bed with my parents by my side. The physical injuries healed, of course, but the mental scars from that night haunt me still to this day. I was afraid to leave the hospital. Then when I did go home, I was afraid to leave the house. The nightmares, flashbacks, new fear of people, fear of the darkâ€¦. It all started then.

What has this got to do with Rutland Food Bank, you ask?
Well, nothing.
But while I was once doing quite well and was going out walking everyday, I have allowed myself to become stuck in a rut again - afraid to go out apart from a few regular places that I know, when I have someone to go with me...

This morning I really wanted to go for a walk, but, I found myself "stuck". Too afraid to get in the car and go... This is crazy. I used to walk around Hambleton Peninsular almost every day, and now I find myself too scared to go... I need an incentive...

So, I have decided that I need to tell the world (well, Rutland anyway!) that I'm going for a walk, so that you can hold me to account if I don't! But more than that, I thought it would be nice if I can raise some money for those in the local community who are struggling at the moment. 

I'm going to try to walk1000miles again in 2021 having not completed the challenge during 2020 - and to start me off I would like to walk the first 5 days for the people of Rutland. I will walk around Hambleton Peninsular at Rutland water once each day and hope to raise Â£50 for Rutland Food Bank - any more than that would be fantastic! I myself will donate Â£2 per day which I will add as one payment of Â£10 at the end of the 5 days.

(I just want to add a little disclaimer here incase any new Covid Restrictions come into force which prevent me from walking around Hambleton Peninsular on any or all of the first 5 days of January. If this does happen I will walk as soon as any new restrictions are lifted.)

Description:
A group of 15 soldiers from 3Rifles will be embarking on a charity to Cycle, Tab, run and walk the distance of 3700.5 miles in 2months, starting 06/05/20 ending 06/07/20. 

The miles is from Edinburgh to Italy, Spain, France, London and back up to Edinburgh. These are the worse affected European countries for COVID-19. 

Each member will aim to do about 246.07 miles in 2months, roughly about 4.11 miles per day. All money raised will go towards food banks. This is to cater for emergency supplies to help the thousands of people who have lost their jobs, and in dire need for basic food, and other necessities. Lets not forget the homeless, as we know that some of our veterans are also homeless and they depend heavily on food banks. 

To that end the team is humbly appealing for any amount of donation that you could contribute to go toward families and homeless people badly affected by COVID-19.

Description:
Hello. Like many people I've been running to try and stay sane during the lockdown. My mileage has crept up to approaching a half marathon, so  I thought I'd push through to 13.1 miles and use it as an opportunity to try and raise some money for good causes. 

Primarily I'm raising money for the local food bank so they can help people struggling during the incoming recession. I'll also donate an additional 50% of whatever I raise to Music Venues Trust, who are trying to stop grassroots music venues from closing. Across the UK, 35% of venues have closed after the last decade. With venues forced to close during the lockdown, and possibly some of the last businesses to re-open, there's a real risk that many more will close without our support in the coming months. Thanks!

As I'll be running on my own, I will only be competing against myself when I ran a half marathon a decade ago. If I don't beat Young Robin on the first go I will keep going until I do. In the interests of transparency, my previous time was 1 hour 44 minutes, which is incidentally faster than TV's Andrew Lincoln who ran the Cardiff Half the same year.

Description:
Anyone who knows me well knows that I like presents. A lot. But what I like even more is food. I am fortunate enough to be able to eat food whenever I want. Lots of people can't and that makes me sad. So this year I'm donating my birthday to the Colchester Food Bank and I want you to make me happy by giving my present to this brilliant organisation and making Christmas just that little bit easier for people who are struggling.

Here's how it works:

For those of you who love me dearly - You need to donate one pound for every one of my glorious years. I'll do the maths for you, that's 33 pounds each. No sharing.

For those of you who like me but not enough to get me a present - fair enough. If you'd like to give even a few pounds as a token of your appreciation that would be awesome.

For those of you who are super organised and already got me a present - fear not. Christmas is just around the corner.

Description:
We are sleeping out in cardboard boxes overnight on the 25th January with our scout troop to raise funds for our local foodbank.  It is going to be very cold (-1deg) but we hope it will be dry and for once we are hoping that it does not snow!!

But we will not be hungry, unlike the increasing number of local people referred to the Greenwich Foodbank where they are provided with   nutritionally balanced emergency food and support.  Greenwich Foodbank is part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. We are proud to support this local charity. 

We would very much appreciate if you could make a small donation to our chosen charity the Greenwich Foodbank.

Title: Ellie 's 500km run in 80 days challenge

Description:
UPDATE: We have now completed the challenge....I can confirm that we made it safely to Newfoundland in the given time but will give a fuller update at the end of the week with exactly how far...

Thank you to those of you who have donated so far- we are thrilled to have made our fundraising target in supporting Portsmouth Foodbank. For those of you who have not yet donated, there is, of course, still plenty of time to do so.

From 23rd May, 16 tutors and two Heads of Year will be taking on an epic journey. The Middle School team will be attempting to cover the distance from Portsmouth Grammar School to Newfoundland, Canada- some 3935 km.

Over the course of a month the team will be running, cycling, walking, rowing- anything that can be measured safely whilst respecting current rules on social distance and exercise- in order to raise money for Portsmouth Foodbank. 

The Middle School team has always worked together very closely: our Common Room space acts as an important hub for staff as well as pupils, and we run a variety of fun events such as discos, the annual ski trip, our Little Canada adventure and, of course a number of charity  fundraisers. With this ethos in mind, each member of the team plans to contribute to the challenge in whatever way they possibly can, covering distances big or small using their own preferred method.

If we manage to complete the distance before a month is up we will keep count of kms covered and see if there are any other interesting landmarks we can get to. If we don't manage it, we will keep going and see how much longer after the month it takes. 

Finally, the serious bit: the coronavirus pandemic has placed unprecedented strain on foodbank services throughout the UK as more and more people find themselves in difficult financial positions as a result of the changing economic landscape. If you are able to, please do consider donating to support those most in need in our community.

Description:
Ay up mi duk! We're the Calverton Plough Boys. 

We perform a traditional St George's mummers play on the nearest Saturday to St George's Day every year to raise funds for charity ...

... but this year the pubs are shut. 

Ah bum. 

So, instead, we've made a silly film to replace this year's live performance, spliced together from our various places of isolation. We'll be inflicting it on the World Wide Web on Saturday 25 April. We already feel very sorry for you.

Please watch and share the film to literally millions of your friends on social media. Be sure to also share our fundraising link, and donate a few quid to Arnold Food Bank, our chosen charity this year. 

Visit: www.calvertonploughplay.co.uk for more info, and to see the film when it's released!

Description:
It's my first birthday on May 9th! I wish I could be spending it with my friends and family having a great big party, but because of this horrible virus I will be separated from my loved ones. I am a very lucky boy who has lots of lovely things and people keep asking my mummy and daddy what I would like for my birthday. What I'd really like is to be with those I love, but I can't. So what I'd really like is for everyone to have a garden party at their home and to donate any of the money that would be spent on travel, presents or food contributions to go to the Stockport Food bank. 

I'd also love people to send lots of pictures of themselves having loads of fun at my great big party, and now it doesn't matter how far away you are we can all have a big party together on May 9th. 

Stockport food Bank provides support and food parcels across Stockport, providing food to people in crisis.

Title: Merritt's Trek to Eton

Description:
Since our launch in October 2012 Angus foodbank has received donations of 178 tons of food and fed 19,000 people 4,700 being children.  We work with over 100 organisations who refer people to our foodbank, who through various circumstances are unable to afford to buy enough food to keep body and soul together.

Many of the people who come to the foodbank are very embarrassed and and down trodden but it is amazing how often they will return up to a year  later and remind us that they received a food parcel but that having found a new job or help with their situation they now want to make a donation back to the foodbank.

However we still need money to run the foodbank, to pay utility bills, purchase and running costs for our delivery van and other expenses.  We have 1 paid member of staff, our Manager, and 80 volunteers who do a power of work collecting and sorting the donated food and dealing with the people who are in need in a caring and compassionate way.

YOUR HELP IS APPRECIATED

Title: 24 Hour Gaming Marathon

Description: The Stepping Out for S6 campaign is a challenge to individuals to complete 60k steps in a given time to raise money for S6 Foodbank. Every donation made goes directly to support their work. Without the assistance of people and businesses in Sheffield, S6 Foodbank wouldnt be able to continue to support their guests, launch new sites and tackle the ongoing food crisis in Sheffield which is being exacerbated by coronavirus.S6 Foodbank are expecting the increased need to continue for the foreseeable future, as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. A donation of Â£27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three for three days. I am aiming to raise at least Â£40 to help S6 Foodbank reach their Â£40,000 target. Whatever I raise (up to that target) will be match-funded by the Government via the Love Your Neighbour partnership, meaning S6 Foodbank receives double the amount.Thank you for sponsoring me, and a huge thank you too from Chris and the team
Title: Vicky's Stepping Out for S6

Description:
My name is Freddie. I am 5 years old and I am cycling as much as I can to raise money for our local Foodbank in Earlsfield, London. 

My goal originally was to cycle 50 miles before school starts at the beginning of June but now I am trying to get to over 100! I am nearly there now. 

St Andrew's engages and support many charitable causes with the aim of helping those in need in Earlsfield and beyond. Responding to the Covid-19 crisis, they support a range of community initiatives including: - The Community Kitchen: Their usually vibrant Home Community CafÃ© at St Andrews Church is now the community's kitchen. Cooking hot meals for the vulnerable and needy. - Earlsfield Foodbank: The Foodbank is being run temporarily from St Andrews as well. Food is distributed from the church every Thursday, with home deliveries to the housebound. The Earlsfield Community Response Fund will help them help with the costs of such inspiring community initiatives and will be available for other groups who need funds.Everyone cared for; no one alone.

Description:
Like many many folk I have watched U.K. politics with sense of concern about what is happening. 

Iâ€™m one person. And I donâ€™t feel equipped academically or politically to change things. But I want to try. So this is my first tiny step.

Title: Be Wrapped up in a Maria woolly hug

Description: My challenge is to run 10k a week, for 10 weeks, starting this week (8th June 2020) and raise some money for UK foodbanks.I enjoy running because it makes me feel energised and relaxed, and I get to race my Dad! If you see me running please cheer me on.
Title: Oscar's10k a week for 10 weeks

Description:
Okay so here goes. From the 1 January 2021, I will be holding my legs accountable to all sorts of running shenanigans. Iâ€™m on Strava, FitBit premium and will be posting on Instagram: emlouxjones. Over the next 10 (or so) months there will be running and races! I will be out every day and hope to raise money for the Trussell Trust to help support foodbanks in the UK.

Those who know me will know the whirlwind of a weight loss/fitness â€œjourneyâ€ that Iâ€™ve been on over the past 18 months and now this is about giving back. Iâ€™d have laughed if someone told early-20s Emma that sheâ€™d be signing up to 10kâ€™s, half and full marathons! Keep your eyes peeled for dates. If weâ€™ve learnt anything during 2020, itâ€™s that we can never do enough for others. 

I look forward to sharing this all with you!

The Trussell Trust: Our vision is for a UK without the need for food banks. We say this because itâ€™s not right that anyone cannot afford their own food. Thatâ€™s why we are working towards a just, compassionate future, where no one should have to use a food bank to get by. Our vision is ambitious, but we know that if we work together it is possible. We can create a future where nobody goes
hungry, because nobody will allow it â€“ when we work Together for
Change.#TogetherForChange.

Description:
On Sept 8th, members of the Cisco UK Team will be climbing Ben Nevis, Scaffel Pike, and Snowdon, in under 24 hours for the Trussell Trust. 

With 23 miles of walking, and over 3000m vertical ascent, it's a challenge not to be taken lightly, but for a very worthy cause. 

We hope you can support us on our journey, and please take a look at what The Trussell Trust are achieving with your donations.
Title: Cisco UK's National Three Peaks Challenge page

Description:
Theresa May is rightly very concerned about the welfare of her 33 MPs who needlessly lost their job last Thursday due to an electorate who won't do as it is told.

She has pledged to use Tory funds to help in this time of crisis but once Rupert gets wind of his money being used to fund scroungers she will surely U-turn.

The maths is chilling. As we know a solid breakfast costs 8p. If we extrapolate that to 3 meals, allowing a generous double helping for dinner, that is 32p per day.

It could be as long as four months until the next general election so that is 119 days - almost as long as a benefit sanction - these 33 poor souls will need to scrape by on only 28 thousand pounds (20 thousand euros) loss of office payment.

They have taken so much from society, isn't it time we gave them something more?
Title: Feed the 33

Description:
Anyone who knows me knows I hate my hair long... itâ€™s reaching the 3 inch mark and thatâ€™s quite enough. With the barbers shut due to the COVID-19 shutdown and a pair of clippers in hand, Iâ€™m doing a sponsored headshave for the Trussell Trust

Itâ€™s abhorrent in a society as wealthy as ours that people need foodbanks at any time, far less during a global pandemic, but sadly it is the reality. Please sponsor me!

I had planned on doing this other years but always chickened out, but this time if I have been sponsored I will have no choice but to do it. Please sponsor me if you can, you will be helping out a foodbank that does a lot of good work in NI and the rest of the UK. Title: Newcastle harbour xmas day swim

Description:
This year I am trying to complete the challenge of walking one million steps across January and February using my daily lockdown exercise to walk the local streets, beaches, fields and paths!

The challenge takes 59 days and equates to about 10 miles, or just under 17,000 steps a day.

I've just gone past 900,000 steps and so to keep me motivated for the last few days I've created this page to raise some money for foodbanks across the country. If you can spare five or ten pounds to support, I would be very grateful, thank you.

The Trussell Trust's vision is for a UK without the need for food banks as itâ€™s not right that people cannot afford their own food. Thatâ€™s why they are working towards a just, compassionate future, where no one should have to use a food bank to get by #TogetherForChange
Title: One Million Steps in January and February

Description:
Through my work (as Community & Business Liaison Co-ordinator) I have seen the difference that Stoke-on-Trent Foodbank makes to local peopleâ€™s lives and want to, in my own time, raise money to help continue this work for the challenging times ahead with the ongoing economic and social affects of Covid-19 not disappearing soon.

I wanted to take up this challenge to make a difference to my life and that of other people.

I have been working mainly from home with 30 minute walks most days, but to build on this, Iâ€™ve challenged myself to 10,000 steps a day (almost tripling my current daily exercise!).

With stark annual foodbank usage figures reported in April, I wanted to start on my fundraising challenge as soon as possible in May. I am writing this 6 days in, and am looking at the incentive TO KEEP GOING THROUGHOUT MAYâ€¦ so far I have been out completing my daily steps in two 40 minute sessions, or once this week as a 30 x 250m length swim with a 5,000 step walk that day. Iâ€™ve been out rain and shine, squeezing this into my daily schedule, please would you consider giving TO ENCOURAGE ME TO KEEP GOING!

Also, whatever you give will be used to support people experiencing food crisis in Stoke-on-Trent, referred by professionals to SoT Foodbank, given food thanks to the generous donations of local people and welcomed by our amazing volunteers at our 16 centres, and then signposted to where they can get help with the problem that
brought them to us, to MAKE A LONG TERM DIFFERENCE.

Please GIVE to Walk With Us, working towards a #HungerFreeFuture

THANK YOU for your time and interest.
Title: Caroline's Walk With Us Challenge page

Description:
Last year I ran the big food trolley fundraiser in PureGym Shawlands and all our lovely members managed to fill it 4 times!!! However this year with the gyms being shut due to tier 4 restrictions, this wonâ€™t be possible.

I love taking classes, and if you come to them you will know that I dance about like a dafty and put a lot of effort into choreographing them to give you the most enjoyment.

For the 3 weeks throughout lockdown 2.0 in Glasgow I will be running 5 classes every week with a suggested donation to help raise funds for the Glasgow Southwest food bank. 

This year more than ever, families have been hit so hard. Losing jobs and loved ones, Christmas will not be easy. If we can help take one stress away by giving a donation of food, that can ease some pressure for those that need it the most.

For more information on the classes, timetable and suggested donations, please see my Instagram page @kaytee_lifts


Thank you <3

Title: Kay's Fit for Food

Description:
In these horrible times we are in and have ahead of us, I love hearing about all the charity work people are doing and I feel like I want to do my bit for something that I think is getting overlooked in these times. Admittedly i'm not going to be running a marathon or swimming the channel or even walking a 100 laps around my flat I just want to do something silly and raise a little bit of money for someone, all i'm going to be doing is dying my hair my fiances favourite colour of purple. If this dying malarkey fails (because shes doing it lol) i will be having to say good bye to my hair period that i've been trying to grow back for nearly a year now!!!!!!!! i know and understand my target isn't to the colonels level but every little helps but for every extra Â£50 i am agreeing to keep my hair purple/shaved for every month after lockdown aswell. so for example if i raise Â£100 i have to keep my hair purple/shaved until we have been out of lockdown for a month, Â£150 would be 2 months so on and so forth.  

More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, its likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.Were working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that theyre able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.

Title: Richard's Step Up September 2019

Description:
The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity working in 130 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, homeless people, all adult victims of modern slavery and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction.

In Hythe, we've been active as a Church and serving the community for nearly 125 years, including through the provision of practical support in times of need. In recent days our foodbank has seen a spike in usage and individuals are finding it difficult to get out of the house to donate food. We've set up this page so that people can make a monetary donation which can be used to purchase food.

Description:
Thank you for supporting S6 Foodbank. Every donation made goes directly to support their work.

Without the assistance of people and businesses in Sheffield, S6 Foodbank wouldnt be able to continue to support their guests, launch new sites and tackle the ongoing food crisis in Sheffield which is being exacerbated by coronavirus.

S6 Foodbank are expecting the increased need to continue for the foreseeable future, as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. 

A donation of Â£27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three for three days. I am aiming to raise at least Â£40 to help S6 Foodbank reach their Â£40,000 target. Whatever I raise (up to that target) will be match-funded by the Government via the Love Your Neighbour partnership, meaning S6 Foodbank receives double the amount.

Thank you for sponsoring me, and a huge thank you too from Chris and the team
Title: ALEXANDRA's Stepping out for S6

Description:
Iâ€™ve got an extraordinarily large amount of hair, so Iâ€™m doing a fundraiser and shaving it off. The proceeds will go to Glasgow NE Foodbank. In addition, all my lovely hair is going to be used to mop up oil spills through the organisation Matter of Trust (www.matter of trust.org). Kinda cool, right?! I am grateful for every single donation that helps me reach my goal of Â£1,000 for Glasgow NE Foodbank. 

My head will be shaved on the 10th June, which would have been my little brother Bradâ€™s 60th birthday. I still miss him and he would have totally been behind me in helping other people.

The pictures after shaving my head will be awesome! Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

On Monday 10th May, we will be celebrating Charity Day, which will coincide with the beginning of Christian Aid Week and the end of Ramadan.

We encourage children to come to school dressed in clothes they already have at home that represent who they are and will also be raising money and collecting donations for the local Foodbank. Children will be encouraged to bring EITHER a donation of 50p OR non-perishable food item e.g. a tin of beans, a box of cereal.

During the day, each class will look at the concept of charity and charitable actions from the viewpoint of a different religion. Keep an eye on the school website to find out what we discovered!

Title: London to Cambridge bike ride

Description:
I can not believe i am writing this because i hate running.

I swore i would never have the time, comittment, stamina, or desire to run a marathon.

But here we are... i cannot think of a better cause than supporting local families who are struggling to put food on the table.

No child, no person, should ever feel the pang of hunger or shame for not having the means to provide food.

So yes i can absolutely train for a marathon, its a luxury.

I havent signed up for an event as i have no idea when theyll be on so id like to get it done before thats a possiblity - this side of Summer.

Im thinking May. 

Ill be running alone. Did i mention i hate running? 

I know most of my friends are fit runners and this isnt a big deal but i havent run further than 13 miles ever and ive had a 2 year hiatus since having my daughter so please show some sympathy (money) and donate to this charity if you can.

Boring, moaning updates and sweaty selfies to follow.

Title: Aarav and Anoush's  fundraiser

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page 

Last year I decided to support my Muslims students by committing to do half of Ramadan with them. The experience gave me an insight into the difficulties faced by many who have access to little food on a day-to-day basis. This insight has motivated me to try to complete the full 30 days this year to support both my students and charities who work to ease the impact of food poverty in the local area. I will be collecting donations for the foodbank whilst I complete my fast so please have a dig in your cupboards for tinned/packeted food, go out and spend a pound on some food or send some money my way to purchase some food on your behalf. I will happily come and collect donations so please let me know if you have anything to give. I've already had Â£20 off some lovely people to set the ball rolling â¤ï¸

38% of households in Stoke-on-Trent are living on less than Â£16,000 per year (the minimum amount required to access basic goods and services in Britain. Hardship Commission â€“ Stoke-on-Trent, 2015).

Title: Ann's Zip wire challenge

Description:
Dear friends and colleagues, 

Welcome to our third annual winter fundraiser! Last year we raised Â£500 for Jimmy's homeless shelter, so we hope we can top that! This year we are raising funds for the Cambridge City Foodbank again. Winter can be very difficult for those in our communities who are struggling, and the holidays can exacerbate that. The Foodbank is seeded by the Trussell Trust and provides food, sanitary and household supplies, and meter cards for gas and electricity to people in need. 

Food bank use is at an all-time high in the UK and your donations of food and money will go a long way. This winter, help people who are forced to decide to 'heat or eat', and bring some holiday comfort to people in need! Here's how you can help:

1. Donate food. If you are based in the Department of Archaeology, please take part in our food drive. There is a box in the coffee room for supplies and updated shopping lists alongside it.

2. Donate money using this page.

You can get more info about the Cambridge City Food Bank here: https://cambridgecity.foodbank.org.uk/

Thank you for your donations!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

50% of my revenue from online teaching during the Covid-19 crisis will go to Lewisham Food Bank to provide emergency food supplies to people who need it most.

4327 three-day emergency food supplies were given to people in crisis last year. An emergency pack contains three-daysâ€™ nutritionally balanced, non-perishable tinned and dried foods

During this time especially, there are many people in need of emergency food supplies. Please donate whatever you can (even Â£1 helps) or to your local food bank. 

Find your local food bank: https://www.trusselltrust.org/get-help/find-a-foodbank/

We as a local community studio based in Brockley, London SE4 wanted to support a local charity during this time and so our team of experienced yoga and pilates teachers will be holding a Yogathon for Lewisham food bank on the 2nd May 2020.

The food banks provide food parcels to be delivered to those in need. People that live in poverty as well as the vulnerable that are isolated. 

During the event our team of teachers will be holding an event in which all the experienced participating teachers will teach a segment of a longer class. It will be a way of connecting our community that since going fully virtual has expanded to people all around the world. It will also be an opportunity to experience all our amazing teachers in a single afternoon during what could be a really crazy random class. 

If you wish to be involved you can either sign up for the event and donate directly or even get sponsored for your participation. If you are not able to participate but would like to donate directly please do. It will not be easy as it will be about 2 hours long but will be a lot of fun!!!. You can rest as much as you need so donâ€™t be too scared of joining in and looking after yourself during the event.

Please support us, to support the food banks as during this time the poverty and hardships that people are experiencing are even more prominent than usual.

Title: Keep Ayrshire Fed Initiative

Description:
We are the Womxn's football team from Goldsmiths university finding a way to keep active during lockdown whilst also helping and giving back the community we live in. Our aim is to collectively run a marathon through our daily jogs and walks, by the 15th of Feb. 

The Charity we have chosen to support is the Lewisham Food Bank which provides essential and emergency food supplies to the local community. 40% of children in Lewisham live below the poverty line and the foodbank was able to provide over 4000 emergency food supply packages last year alone. In the current climate, it is necessary more than ever to support the community and the good people around us. Please help us reach this goal! 

GWF

Title: Lee's #75 Hard Challenge

Description:
The challenge: To notice one small thing/detail in my environment each day this month and to share it on the Facebook page, as either a photo, tiny piece of art or haiku. Some of these may be wonderful, some may be terrible. The idea is to do it and share it regardless!


Why: Over the last 2 years or so, illness and disability have left me almost housebound and needing a lot of time in bed.
I've decided I need to set myself one tiny, manageable creative goal each day to stop life just passing by in a blur.

At the same time I still want to find ways to contribute to my community and to things that mean a lot to me.
Combining my little daily goal with a fundraiser seemed one way I could do that.

If you'd like to follow along, whether you donate or not, please come and visit the Noticing September Facebook page

Title: In Memory of Colin Parker

Description:
The Challenge I have set myself a challenge of cycling 3,337 miles. This virtual challenge will start in Montreal and go through Ottawa, Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton and Calgary before ending in Vancouver.

On top of this I will be "lifting the Stanley cup", not the actual trophy but weights equivalent to it (15.65kgs). Doesn't sound like much but each team has 20 players on it and the 7 Canadian teams have won 54 Stanley cups between them meaning I will be lifting it 1,080 times totalling 16,902kgs.

Why am I doing this? 2020 was an awful year for so many. With the economy in ruins, businesses struggling and staff being made redundant, even more people are living below the breadline. I'm looking to do what I can to help raise money for this amazing charity so that no one has to worry where their next meal comes from or how they are going to cut corners to feed children/loved ones.

Information about the charity Manchester Central Foodbank was founded in 2013 by a group of students connected with the Manchester Universities Catholic Chaplaincy who were passionate about tackling food poverty and making sure that those in the local community experiencing emergency food poverty would be supported.

Since then we have operated out of the Catholic Chaplaincy on Oxford Road, primarily serving the local community of Ardwick , Longsight, City Centre and parts of East Manchester. No. 93 (formerly the Harpurhey Wellbeing Centre) opened it's doors in November 2020 and in the first month they have already distributed 66 emergency food parcels which is equivalent to 600 meals.

We donâ€™t think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. Thatâ€™s why we provide three daysâ€™ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis. We are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK.

For more details on the amazing work being done, please visit www.manchestercentral.foodbank.org.uk

So why a Canadian theme you ask? Everyone who knows me, knows my love of ice hockey and Canada is the home of hockey. Due to the global pandemic, the NHL restructured all divisions so for 2021 there will be an all-Canadian division.

How will I record progress? This will be either via the Strava app (if I'm on my bike) or the LFConnect app (if I'm in the gym). Don't worry, I will screenshot my progress so you don't think I'm cheating.

When does this challenge start? I will officially start the challenge on 13th January 2021. This is the start of the 2020-2021 season.

When does this challenge end? I must finish both parts of the challenge before the Stanley Cup is awarded, the latest this can be is 9th July 2021. This gives me 177 days to finish (if not sooner).

Giving Please donate what you can. All money goes directly to this fantastic charity with every penny put to use, making sure those who are most in need of help don't go without food. If you are a UK tax payer you can add Gift Aid, meaning your donation goes that little bit further and the charity can claim more from the government.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Title: Lewis 's christmas donations

Description:
June 2020 during a global pandemic I woke up inspired to do everything I have never done before... make ME happy. Iâ€™ve spent the last 4/5 years unhappy with my; motivation, fitness, weight and just all round mental health. Iâ€™ve tried every diet going and been to the gym a million and one times yet still was getting nowhere. One evening after work I thought F*** THIS and downloaded the couch to 5k app, with some motivation from the mother in law that sheâ€™d do it with me, out we went. 


Iâ€™ve not stopped since.


After 9 weeks of the couch to 5k I continued to run 5k for a minimum of 3 times a week, occasionally adding a 4th in to challenge myself. As months went by I decided to increase the kmâ€™s and keep pushing myself and my body to itâ€™s fullest potential. It actually blows my mind what you can put your body through, no matter how tired you are or if your body aches. 


The time I spend running is the time I spend on ME, and everyone deserves time spent on themselves. 


After years of not even being able to go into a shop alone without having a full blown panic attack I am challenging myself to run the potters arf marathon alone (I wanna be sick). 


After a colleague from work mentioned the Stoke-on-Trent Foodbank and what their charity stood for, it became clear that after the past 12 months this is the charity I wanted to raise money for. 


The Stoke-on-Trent Foodbank aim to provide 3 days of emergency food to those who are in crisis either due to; poverty, sudden loss of income, bereavement, domestic violence, illness and other crisis within their family. 

Their services include; money or debt advice, specialist housing support, mental health, drug and alcohol issues and social care. 


Highlighted above are just some of the services that COVID would of made 10x harder for families during this pandemic. 


With the help from my lovely family and friends I am hoping to raise enough money to help Stoke-on-Trent. Any money donated is very highly appreciated ðŸ¥ºðŸ’˜ðŸ’˜ðŸ’˜

Title: I'm going to slowly disappear...... well not completely!

Description:
As somebody who was lucky enough to be born round about this
time of year, Decemberâ€™s always been a month of receiving for me. This year Iâ€™d like to change that, and instead of receiving presents Iâ€™d like to give something back to a community that is now in need of help more than ever.

Having had a rather hedonistic time at uni (still embarrassed
about that time I ate a whole pasta bake for four in one sitting tbh), and in light of the political events of last week, Iâ€™ve been doing a lot of reflecting on my own relative privilege and the state of the world around me. You canâ€™t really turn on the news, or go on social media without being reminded that the world is a Horrible Place, and thereâ€™s very little you can do about it. Bad people are in charge, everything is getting hotter, and Iâ€™m never going to reach 5â€™4â€. Itâ€™s all very disheartening.

So if other people canâ€™t make good things happen, Iâ€™m going
to try my very best to do it myself. During the pre-election madness, I saw numerous statistics on Twitter that really shocked me, and in particular quite a few on food bank usage in the UK. More people are using food banks than ever before, and this number has increased from the tens of thousands in 2010 to the millions this year. The reasons behind this increase can be disputed to no end, but I think regardless of political persuasion you can agree that theyâ€™re a
highly valuable resource for many. One that shouldnâ€™t need to exist, but one that pretty much means life or death for those that need them.

For that reason Iâ€™d like to collect donations for the North
Bristol Foodbank this year, the foodbank thatâ€™s local to both myself and many of you that I know. Thereâ€™s been a 54% increase in demand from North Bristol foodbank from April-Sept 2019, and as the winter draws in, the demand only increases. Christmas isnâ€™t going to be the best time of year for many, and even if you canâ€™t donate I hope you can keep them on your mind over the festive season.

Iâ€™ve created this page for any donations youâ€™d like
to make! I would appreciate them much more than any Christmas/birthday presents (although if youâ€™ve already bought them, I wonâ€™t say noâ€¦), and theyâ€™ll do much more good as well. Also, if youâ€™re around to give me something in person, you have no excuse now ðŸ˜Š

Title: Georgina's Veganuary

Description:
Badreddin Salhani-Maat (17-11-1947 to 31-03-2020)


Bob was born in Syria and later reluctantly came to the UK to support his father to become a gynaecologist.  After a few years he decided to stay on in the UK while his family returned back to Syria.  He fell into a career as a maths teacher.   Despite his deteriorating vision he carried into his 50s. He was a kind hearted and generous man who touched many lives.  Nothing was impossible. He raised three independent children who will be forever grateful for all he did for them.  He acquired a few extra children who saw as equals to his own children.  He has four beautiful grand children who adore him.  He will be truly missed. 


Instead of flowers and cards, he would have preferred donations to those in need. He always enjoyed feeding the troops.

Since social distancing began, I have a lot more time to create art and have been painting almost every day. I want to put this burst of creativity to good use by supporting charities that are helping during the current Covid-19 crisis. I've suggested Lewisham Food Bank, as it help those in the borough where I teach, but if you want to make a donation to another charity just let me know and I will send you some art :)

If you would like to receive some unique artwork, I will send it to you (covering postage) in exchange for a donation to the food bank or another charity. Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my SECOND Just Giving page. With your help I have already raised over Â£500 for one Food charity; I would love to repeat that again this time for the Black Country Foodbank. 

Hello my name is Dillon and I am a student at Haberdashers Adams Grammar School. Like you I am worried about the effect Covid-19 is having on us all. I have seen on the news that many people are struggling with work meaning that they may not be able to buy food for their families and that is something I want to personally help with. I have done a charity car wash in my local area but now want to do something even bigger. 

So, I have decided to change the colour of my hair in support of the NHS. I am going to dye my hair in NHS Blue to show my appreciation for all the amazing work they are doing for us. All of the money raised will be used to buy as much food as possible. I hope that you will all support me in this worthwhile cause. 

I have already raised over Â£500 for another foodbank charity called The Trussell Trust; I would now like to provide the same help and support to Black Country Foodbank. I know that if we all come together we can not only achieve this goal but smash it.

Finally, please do keep looking back at this page for updates and pictures and don't forget to share with your family, friends and work colleagues.
